Yishay Mor wrote:

> Help me out, please -
> 
> 
> I'm trying to "market" JUnit to my team. The most common objection I get 
> goes along the line of "what advantage will I get out of this, when 
> writing my code? I have my test class, w/ its main(..) method, and 
> that's all I need."
> 
> Even though people are willing to see the advantage of a unit testing 
> framework for the long term project development, that want to see 
> "personal value".
> 

If they really did have a test class that gets run frequently and 
automatically checks its results, then they would already be 
experiencing the personal values - more time to write code with 
confidence.

My experience has been that the personal value of time strikes a chord 
with most developers.  It takes time to write the tests, but well 
focused tests continue to pay a return on the investment by 
automatically checking results and instilling confidence that adding new 
features didn't break anything.  Without automated tests, your 
development pace suffers from the constant drag of having to manually 
inspect results with every code change.  It doesn't take long to realize 
that the manual process doesn't scale particularly well.
